questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ruth 1:1-18 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone of Naomi's decision to return and Ruth's declaration in verses 16-17.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'where' in Ruth's declaration (v.16)
Pay attention to the contrast between Naomi's initial hope and her current bitterness (v.10-11)
The phrase 'your people shall be my people' (v.16) shows a deep commitment to identity

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Naomi, Elimelech, Ruth, Orpah), what (leaving Bethlehem due to famine, Elimelech's death, marriage of sons to Moabite women, return to Bethlehem after ten years), where (Bethlehem to Moab and back), and why (famine and death of sons).
tips: Include the famine as the cause for leaving Bethlehem
Note that Elimelech dies in Moab
Mention that after ten years, both sons die

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Ruth's declaration (v.16-17), Naomi's name change (v.15), or the decision to return (v.10).
tips: Ruth's declaration: 'Where you go I will go...' shows an unbreakable commitment
Naomi's name change from Naomi (pleasant) to Mara (bitter) reflects her emotional state
The phrase 'your people shall be my people' (v.16) is a profound statement of identity shift

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to the Israelites about God and loyalty through this passage?
tips: The passage shows that even a Moabite (non-Israelite) can become part of God's people through loyalty
This foreshadows how Gentiles will be included in the church through Christ
The author emphasizes that true loyalty to God transcends ethnic and cultural boundaries

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cultural context of Moabites, the name change of Naomi, and the concept of Ruth's loyalty as a covenant commitment.
tips: Moabites were considered enemies of Israel in ancient times, so Ruth's choice to follow Naomi was a radical act of faith
The name 'Mara' (bitter) is a temporary name that reflects Naomi's current state, but it's a sign of God's sovereignty in her life
Ruth's declaration in v.16-17 is a covenant commitment that goes beyond cultural norms

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be like Ruth in your loyalty to God when circumstances are difficult? What specific step can you take this week?
tips: Identify an area where you might be 'going your own way' and choose to follow God's call
Practice the declaration of Ruth: 'Where you go I will go' by committing to follow God's lead
Think about what it means to 'die with your people' in a modern context

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about Ruth's loyalty and the promise of God's provision for the return to Bethlehem.
tips: Thank God for Ruth's example of unwavering loyalty
Pray for the courage to follow God even when it's costly
Ask God to help you see your identity in Him, not in the world

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ruth 2:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'happens' (v.2) and Ruth's loyalty declaration (v.16).
tips: Notice the phrase 'happens' (v.2) and the emphasis on Ruth's loyalty (v.16)
Pay attention to Boaz's command to the reapers (v.16-17)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Ruth and Boaz), WHAT (Ruth gleans in Boaz's field), WHERE (in Bethlehem), and WHY (Ruth's loyalty to Naomi and Boaz's role as kinsman-redeemer).
tips: Ruth's decision to follow Naomi to Bethlehem
Boaz's kindness to Ruth (staying with his servants, leaving grain)
The ephah of barley Ruth returns with

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Ruth's loyalty (v.16), Boaz's command to the reapers (v.17), or the ephah of barley (v.17).
tips: Boaz's command shows deliberate kindness beyond law
The ephah (a large measure) symbolizes abundant provision
Ruth's quiet determination to work in the field despite being a foreigner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to Israel about God's providence and kinsman-redeemers?
tips: The story shows God's providence in the midst of hardship
Kinsman-redeemers are a biblical pattern for God's provision in the community
This foreshadows Christ as the ultimate kinsman-redeemer

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of kinsman-redeemer, the practice of gleaning, and Boaz's specific command to leave grain for Ruth.
tips: Kinsman-redeemer: a relative who has the right and duty to redeem land or provide for the family in times of need
Gleaning: a legal practice in Israel where the poor could gather leftover grain after the harvest
Boaz's command shows his intention to provide for Ruth without her having to ask

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice being a 'Boaz' by leaving extra for others this week?
tips: Leave extra time for someone who needs help
Share resources beyond what is required
Be intentional about providing for others without being asked

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray that you become a Boaz in your community, leaving extra for others.
tips: Ask God to help you be a generous provider
Pray for others who are struggling to receive kindness
Thank God for Boaz as a model of kinsman-redeemer

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ruth 3:1-15 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Ruth and Boaz and the emotional intensity of the night encounter.
tips: Notice the phrase 'spread your wings' (Ruth 3:8) as a metaphor for redemption
Pay attention to Boaz's words: 'Blessed are you!' (Ruth 3:9) and the mention of a 'closer redeemer' (Ruth 3:10)
Listen for the contrast between Ruth's boldness and Boaz's initial surprise

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Ruth and Boaz), WHAT (Ruth's initiative to seek Boaz as redeemer), WHERE (the threshing floor at night), and WHY (to secure a future for Naomi).
tips: Include Ruth's preparation: washing, anointing, and dressing in her best clothes
Note Boaz's awakening and Ruth's direct appeal for redemption
Mention the promise of resolution by morning

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Ruth's bold declaration (Ruth 3:8), Boaz's recognition of her faithfulness (Ruth 3:9), or the concept of a 'closer redeemer' (Ruth 3:10).
tips: Ruth's phrase 'spread your wings' shows her confidence in Boaz's role as redeemer
Boaz's acknowledgment that Ruth has not gone after young men (a sign of her purity) is profound
The mention of a 'closer redeemer' adds theological depth to the story

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to Israel about redemption and faithfulness through Ruth's actions?
tips: The passage emphasizes that redemption requires bold initiative and trust in God's provision
It shows that true redemption comes through the 'closer redeemer' (Christ), not just any human redeemer
The author highlights Ruth's faithfulness to Naomi and her commitment to God's covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of a 'closer redeemer', why Boaz says Ruth has 'not gone after young men', and the cultural context of the threshing floor.
tips: The term 'closer redeemer' in Hebrew refers to a more immediate or superior redeemer (Christ)
Boaz's comment about Ruth not going after young men means she has not been seeking a less committed redeemer
The threshing floor at night was a place of vulnerability and work, where a man could be alone

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you take bold initiative like Ruth to seek God's redemption in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you need to take a step of faith (like Ruth's preparation)
Plan to share your needs with God in the context of His provision
Wait for God to reveal the 'closer redeemer' (Christ) in your situation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the example of Ruth's bold faith and initiative. Ask for courage to seek His redemption.
tips: Thank God for providing a redeemer (Christ) for His people
Pray for the courage to take bold steps in seeking God's provision
Ask for the Spirit to reveal the 'closer redeemer' (Christ) in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Ruth 4 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other
